thread.title: Flooded rivers, swollen swamps and full dams at Top End station
thread.title_full: Flooded rivers, swollen swamps and full dams at Top End station

author: Daniel Fitzgerald
title: Flooded rivers, swollen swamps and full dams at Top End station
text:
Map: Katherine 0850 
Plentiful wet season rains have flooded the Roper River, swelled swamps and filled new dams on Moroak Station, south-east of Katherine in the Northern Territory. 
The Roper River , which runs just a few metres from the front door of the station house, has been high since the start of January. 
The Hoar family has been restricted to the homestead since, only venturing further afield by helicopter. 
Despite floodwaters moving downstream from the Waterhouse River, Simon Hoar said he did not think the Roper would break its banks and flood his house. 
"Hopefully it will have enough time to drop a bit here at the house and for [the water] to get away," he said. 
"[The river] is still moving. It hasn't backed up, which is good." 
Mr Hoar said the much of the soil on the station was waterlogged due to heavy rains in January and February. 
"Everywhere is absolutely full of water. The runoff from the rivers into the swamps has filled them to the brim," he said. 
"All the cattle are up on the ridges in the higher country. They are staying out of the lower blacksoil country." Photo: A new 50 million litre dam has filled with water at Moroak Station. (Supplied: Moroak Station) 
Rain and runoff filled several 50 million litre dams, built on the property last year, for the first time. 
"They were a lot of money to put in, fuel and machinery hours, so it was good to them fill up straight away," Mr Hoar said. 
"There were no dramas. They filled up well with no [erosion] damage. We've been pretty lucky." 
Mr Hoar said the good start to the wet season left him feeling confident about the year ahead. 
"We have had plenty of rain, so it will be a bit later start to our mustering I would say," he said. 
"Then everything should power ahead with our cattle, weight-wise. 
"The grass is looking good at the moment. It will hold on a bit longer this year." 
Mr Hoar said he was keeping himself busy during the wet season by manufacturing gates for new yards, ready to be put up in the dry season.
